instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00244: What is 820-00244? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.PP3V3R3V0_AON: What is PP3V3R3V0_AON? PP3V3R3V0_AON is the first power rail you need to get a USB-C charger to go from 5v to 20v on an A1534 Macbook with an 820-00045 board..
definitions.PP5V_G3H: What is PP5V_G3H? PP5V_G3H is a 5v rail present when the machine is in a G3H mechanical off state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Liquid damaged usb-c and audio boards/cable.

Usb-C board doesnt look bad afaik its just corrosion on the contacts which i have cleared up.
Measured rails and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> is missing with a 19ohm short? to gnd

Also how does the disconnect battery button work?

Usb-c board on the way, cant find replacement audio board so testing without it atm

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message: 19 Ohm to GND on 5V is of course way too low. Inject voltage and see if anything heats up.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
My bad, was measuring while battery was still connected resistance now 20k+
Traced back and <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> is not getting EN (<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>) now a bit confused as it seems this comes from the cpu but it needs s0 rails to power up?

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>     8.67v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>      8.68v
<SIGNAL>PPVBUS_LIO</SIGNAL>      14.8v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>     3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3R3V0_AON</SIGNAL>     3.279v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>    3.073v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3H</SIGNAL>    4.99v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>        4.99v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>        0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>    3.33v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yeah, this is gonna suck. All I can say is to inspect the board for corrosion. Charging circuit seems to work as you have 15V on the input so it is talking to the charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message: the only corrosion on the board was a tiny bit near <TRANSISTOR>Q7291</TRANSISTOR>, will try ultrasonic and see what happens

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Inspect very closely before cleaning, crucial evidence will be lost!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I have taken pictures of both sides, Well after ultrasonic it now boots.
It was running off of battery after cleaning, because I dont have a usb-c hub i let it charge up to 50% so it would let me install osx.
Now in osx, its saying 64% "Replace Now" and wont run off of the battery at all nor charge the battery, now when the machine is off and I plug in charger it comes up with the battery screen with 0% but before it was displaying fine but once booted in osx it will say 64%

threads.message: but it was working for a bit and stats all come up in the about this mac section, WIll check current resistors when i get back tomorrow. Any other ideas?
